member.name: M:SheetWorx.CellTable.Tree.BPlusTree.ExtendToRow(SheetWorx.Core.RowIndex)
member.summary: Extends the tree to the given row.
member.param: The row to which the tree should be extended.

remarks.para: If the tree already extends to or beyond , no action is taken.
If the last range in the tree is smaller than the maximum allowed size, this range is extended as far as necessary, up to the maximum allowed size.
If the tree still does not extend to , additional blocks are added as required, with the final added block being the minimum size necessary.

member.name: M:SheetWorx.CellTable.Tree.BPlusTree.ShiftRangesAfter(SheetWorx.Core.RowIndex,System.Int32)

member.param: The of the first row to be shifted.

member.name: M:SheetWorx.CellTable.Tree.InternalNode.InsertNode(SheetWorx.CellTable.CellBlockRange,SheetWorx.CellTable.Tree.INode)
member.summary: Inserts a new child node into this node. This is called by a node when it splits.
member.param: The key for the node being added.
The node to be added.

remarks.para: is the lowest range existing in the node being added (if it is a leaf node) or in leaf nodes under the node being added (if it is an internal node).
When the node is full it must be split. In this scenario, the middle key is promoted to the parent node, with a pointer to the new node.
When all is complete, we want MinimumKeysPerNode keys in the existing node and MaximumKeysPerNode - MinimumKeysPerNode in the new node (with one promoted key).

First of all we copy enough keys to the new node such that once we've done the insertion, there will be MinimumKeysPerNode + 1 keys in the original node. The number copied depends on whether the insertion will be into the existing or new node.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance in the specific scenario of a full leaf node splitting because of an insertion.
member.param: The tree which owns the new node.

The block indices of the node which has split.
The leaf node which is next after the new node, or if the new node is the last leaf node.
The leaf node which is prior to the new node, i.e. the node which has split.

member.name: T:SheetWorx.Formatting.Alignment.HorizontalAlignment
member.summary: Specifies how text in a cell should be aligned horizontally.

list.item: When or is set, orientation is reset to .

When is selected, only complete repeats of the text will be made, and the text will only be repeated when the full extent of any repeats can be accommodated within the width of the cell. The text will be aligned to the left.

member.name: F:SheetWorx.Formatting.Alignment.HorizontalAlignment.Center
member.summary: Specifies that the cell text should be horizontally centered.

member.name: F:SheetWorx.Formatting.Alignment.HorizontalAlignment.CenterAcrossSelection
member.summary: Specifies that the cell text should be horizontally centered relative to its own cell and any empty cells to its right.

member.name: F:SheetWorx.Formatting.Alignment.HorizontalAlignment.Distributed
member.summary: Specifies that the cell text should be horizontally justified, including the last line.

member.name: F:SheetWorx.Formatting.Alignment.HorizontalAlignment.Fill
member.summary: Specifies that the cell text should be repeated as many times as necessary in order to extend fully from the left edge of the cell to the right edge.

member.name: F:SheetWorx.Formatting.Alignment.HorizontalAlignment.General
member.summary: Specifies that text values should be left justified, numerical values (including dates and times) should be right justified and logical and error values should be centered.

member.name: F:SheetWorx.Formatting.Alignment.HorizontalAlignment.Justify
member.summary: Specifies that the cell text should be horizontally justified, with the last line being aligned to the left.

member.name: F:SheetWorx.Formatting.Alignment.HorizontalAlignment.Left
member.summary: Specifies that the cell text should be aligned to the left.

member.name: F:SheetWorx.Formatting.Alignment.HorizontalAlignment.Right
member.summary: Specifies that the cell text should be aligned to the right.

member.name: T:SheetWorx.Formatting.Alignment.VerticalAlignment
member.summary: Specifies how text in a cell should be aligned vertically.

member.name: F:SheetWorx.Formatting.Alignment.VerticalAlignment.Bottom
member.summary: Specifies that the cell text should be aligned to the bottom of the cell.

member.name: F:SheetWorx.Formatting.Alignment.VerticalAlignment.Center
member.summary: Specifies that the cell text should be aligned to the vertical center of the cell.

member.name: F:SheetWorx.Formatting.Alignment.VerticalAlignment.Distributed
member.summary: When the text is horizontal, specifies that the lines of cell text should be evenly distributed across the entire height of the cell. When the text is rotated to a vertical orientation, each line is justified across the height of the cell, including the last line.

member.name: F:SheetWorx.Formatting.Alignment.VerticalAlignment.Justify
member.summary: When the text is horizontal, specifies that the lines of cell text should be evenly distributed across the entire height of the cell. When the text is rotated to a vertical orientation, each line is justified across the height of the cell, except for the last line which is aligned to the left of its vertical direction.

member.name: F:SheetWorx.Formatting.Alignment.VerticalAlignment.Top
member.summary: Specifies that the cell text should be aligned to the top of the cell.

member.name: M:SheetWorx.Maths.SpecialFunctions.SpecialFunctions.GammaLn(System.Double)
member.summary: Computes the logarithm of the Gamma function.
member.param: The argument of the gamma function.
member.returns: The logarithm of the gamma function.

remarks.para: This implementation of the computation of the gamma and logarithm of the gamma function follows the derivation in "An Analysis Of The Lanczos Gamma Approximation", Glendon Ralph Pugh, 2004. We use the implementation listed on p. 116 which achieves an accuracy of 16 floating point digits. Although 16 digit accuracy should be sufficient for double values, improving accuracy is possible (see p. 126 in Pugh).
Our unit tests suggest that the accuracy of the Gamma function is correct up to 14 floating point digits.

member.name: M:SheetWorx.Maths.SpecialFunctions.SpecialFunctions.Gamma(System.Double)
member.summary: Computes the Gamma function.
member.param: The argument of the gamma function.
member.returns: The logarithm of the gamma function.

remarks.para: This implementation of the computation of the gamma and logarithm of the gamma function follows the derivation in "An Analysis Of The Lanczos Gamma Approximation", Glendon Ralph Pugh, 2004. We use the implementation listed on p. 116 which should achieve an accuracy of 16 floating point digits. Although 16 digit accuracy should be sufficient for double values, improving accuracy is possible (see p. 126 in Pugh).
Our unit tests suggest that the accuracy of the Gamma function is correct up to 13 floating point digits.

member.name: M:SheetWorx.Maths.SpecialFunctions.SpecialFunctions.GammaLowerIncomplete(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the lower incomplete gamma function gamma(a,x) = int(exp(-t)t^(a-1),t=0..x) for real a > 0, x > 0.
member.param: The argument for the gamma function.
The upper integral limit.
member.returns: The lower incomplete gamma function.

member.name: M:SheetWorx.Maths.SpecialFunctions.SpecialFunctions.GammaLowerRegularized(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the lower incomplete regularized gamma function P(a,x) = 1/Gamma(a) * int(exp(-t)t^(a-1),t=0..x) for real a > 0, x > 0.
member.param: The argument for the gamma function.
The upper integral limit.
member.returns: The lower incomplete gamma function.

member.name: M:SheetWorx.Maths.SpecialFunctions.SpecialFunctions.GammaLowerRegularizedInv(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the inverse P^(-1) of the regularized lower incomplete gamma function P(a,x) = 1/Gamma(a) * int(exp(-t)t^(a-1),t=0..x) for real a > 0, x > 0, such that P^(-1)(a,P(a,x)) == x.

member.param: The location where to evaluate the polynomial at.
The coefficients of the polynomial, coefficient for power k at index k.

member.summary: Represents a color scheme base color specified using HSL (Hue, Saturation, Lightness) representation.

member.name: M:SheetWorx.Themes.Colors.HslSchemeColor.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class using the provided hue, saturation and lightness levels.
member.param: The hue, expressed in six-thousandths of a degree. Values outside the range 0 ≤ hue < 360 x 6000 (21600000) are clamped to this range.
The saturation, expressed in thousandths of one percent. Values outside the range 0 ≤ lightness ≥ 100 x 1000 (100000) are clamped to this range.
The lightness, expressed in thousandths of one percent. Values outside the range 0 ≤ lightness ≥ 100 x 1000 (100000) are clamped to this range.

member.name: P:SheetWorx.Themes.Colors.HslSchemeColor.H
member.summary: Gets the hue, expressed in six-thousandths of a degree. Hue therefore has a value in the range 0 ≤ hue < 360 x 6000 (21600000).

member.name: P:SheetWorx.Themes.Colors.HslSchemeColor.L
member.summary: Gets the lightness, expressed in thousandths of one percent. Lightness therefore has a value in the range 0 ≤ lightness ≥ 100 x 1000 (100000).

member.name: P:SheetWorx.Themes.Colors.HslSchemeColor.S
member.summary: Gets the saturation, expressed in thousandths of one percent. Saturation therefore has a value in the range 0 ≤ lightness ≥ 100 x 1000 (100000).

member.name: T:SheetWorx.Themes.Colors.SchemeColor
member.summary: Represents a color in a color scheme associated with a workbook .
member.remarks:
A consists of two elements:
A of type which specifies the basic properties of the color. Several different classes implement , each providing a different way to specify a color.
A collection of zero or more transforms which each modify the in some way. These transforms are applied to the sequentially, resulting in the output .
The result of applying the transforms to the base color is a which can be obtained using the property.

member.name: P:SheetWorx.Views.WorksheetView.SplitColumn
member.summary: Gets or sets the number of columns to the left of the horizontal split or freeze point, beginning with .
member.remarks: If there is no horizontal split or freeze, this returns zero. Setting this to zero will remove any horizontal split or freeze point. Setting this while panes are frozen will unfreeze panes and replace freeze points with split points, even if it is set to zero when there was no horizontal freeze point. When this is set to a non-zero value, the horizontal split is positioned directly after the specified number of columns, beginning with .

member.name: P:SheetWorx.Views.WorksheetView.SplitHorizontal
member.summary: Gets or sets the position of the horizontal split or freeze point measured in points from the left edge of .
member.remarks: If there is no horizontal split or freeze, this returns zero. Setting this to zero will remove any horizontal split or freeze point. Setting this while panes are frozen will unfreeze panes and replace freeze points with split points, even if it is set to zero when there was no horizontal freeze point. When this is set to a non-zero value, the horizontal split is positioned at the specified number of points to the right of the left edge of .

member.name: P:SheetWorx.Views.WorksheetView.SplitRow
member.summary: Gets or sets the number of rows above the vertical split or freeze point, beginning with .
member.remarks: If there is no vertical split or freeze, this returns zero. Setting this to zero will remove any vertical split or freeze point. Setting this while panes are frozen will unfreeze panes and replace freeze points with split points, even if it is set to zero when there was no vertical freeze point. When this is set to a non-zero value, the vertical split is positioned directly after the specified number of rows, beginning with .

member.name: P:SheetWorx.Views.WorksheetView.SplitVertical
member.summary: Gets or sets the position of the vertical split or freeze point measured in points from the top edge of .
member.remarks: If there is no vertical split or freeze, this returns zero. Setting this to zero will remove any vertical split or freeze point. Setting this while panes are frozen will unfreeze panes and replace freeze points with split points, even if it is set to zero when there was no vertical freeze point. When this is set to a non-zero value, the vertical split is positioned at the specified number of points below the top edge of .

member.summary: Gets or sets the gridline colour as an index into the current colour palette of the workbook.
member.remarks: Setting this to any value will set to . If is set to , this returns -1.

member.name: M:SheetWorx.Utilities.Conversion.BigEndianBitConverter.IsLittleEndian
member.summary: Indicates the byte order ("endianess") in which data is converted using this class.
member.remarks: Different computer architectures store data using different byte orders. "Big-endian" means the most significant byte is on the left end of a word. "Little-endian" means the most significant byte is on the right end of a word.
member.returns: true if this converter is little-endian, false otherwise.

member.summary: Indicates the byte order ("endianess") in which data is converted using this class.
member.remarks: Different computer architectures store data using different byte orders. "Big-endian" means the most significant byte is on the left end of a word. "Little-endian" means the most significant byte is on the right end of a word.
member.returns: true if this converter is little-endian, false otherwise.
